Hi,

The stopping time function is not required and it caused me confusion on the rounding.

There is a closed formula to compute the final position on the ball. exp(-infity) = 0 thus, final position is expressed by x0 + vx/0.8.

I had access to the contribution, but if not, I would have turned in circle for a while before figuring out that the stopping time is an epsilon.

But great problem, I loved doing it.

I agree with what the others said :
- "interesting, though more physics [and maths] than algorithm"
- needing to remove trailing 0s is a bit strange, especially when there are actually non-0 digits later on
- considering the "stopped" position as the limit (hence never actually reached) seems at least as natural as some more or less arbitrary cutoff. So either this should be stated, or (probably better), the test cases should be crafted to avoid having answers exactly (or almost exactly...) at x.yz5.

Interesting puzzle, even though it's more of a textbook physics problem than an algorithm puzzle.

I edited to improve the stub.

When asked for a 2-decimal precision, one expects to always provide these 2 decimals. Here (since you rely on the default behavior of Python) you should mention that you don't want trailing 0s in the output.

Testcases are a bit weak. First, there should be more than 1 "normal" case.
Also, there is a missing particular case: Consider for instance the "normal" testcase and inverse the speed. The solution should be (no collision):
2.63 1.04
1.29 0.56
But your solution code gives:
1.63 0.11
2.29 1.49
I would suggest to add such a case (and fix your code).

very good

Sorry, I have one more thing! :\

I am afraid this is incorrect part in your solution:

def stop_pos(pos, vel):
    return position(pos, vel, stop_time(vel))

It is not exactly the stop position. It is the position of almost stop.
But it is very easy to find the exact stop pos. Just remove e^-0.8t part from your position function:

def stop_pos_correct(pos, vel):
    return pos + vel/.8

I tried to write my own solution and can't pass some tests with verdict:

Found: 2.4 0.81
Expected: 2.4 0.8

I believe not exact stop_pos in your solution may be the cause of this difference.

I like this puzzle! But formalist inside me don't like this specific wording:
"predict the position of two balls after stopping" and "when stopped"

Because there is no stopping moment! Balls will be moving forever with decreasing velocity.

I would suggest to change wording to "position when absolute value of the velocity will become less than EPSILON" or something like that.
Is it a typo in the puzzle name? Collis_S_ion?

Hey, nice idea.

I am not sure about the statement. You say acceleration is 0.8 velocity. So, this would mean the velocity would constantly increase (since acceleration is positive) and in the end, infinite velocity would be reached. I guess you are not talking about acceleration, right? Rephrase, please.

Also, at the output, what is "at the end"? At which time? I guess when the balls stop?

Thanks for commenting!

You're right about the acceleration, I was thinking in terms of vector magnitude, but didn't specified it, 
I'll change that right now.
For the "at the end", I wrote at the beginning "The goal is to predict the position of two balls after stopping", 
I will make it clearer here then.

Thanks again!

Hi,

Here I consider a ball stopped when both components of velocity are in [-1/1000, 1/1000] (because we want a rounded result, a better precision is not necessary).

My quadratic equations are simpler because I consider the motion frictionless (then I verify if the position is reached before the stopping point).

For your test case, I get the same result.

Thanks for your work!
Right, thanks!

My idea was to let the players finding it out by themselves, due to the limited precision required in the output (position rounded to two decimals), it is possible to deduce the value for epsilon!

Do you think it really is necessary to change that? ðŸ¤”

Thanks for the feedback!

Why would the ball not be considered stopped? ðŸ¤”

v*e^(-0.8t) < eps  => t > -log(eps / v) / 0.8
With eps = 1/1000

(In my solution, I use a stricter method by using just one component of the velocity).

I pass all the tests with your function though.
Thanks!

Ok, with this fix in statement this issue is not actual any more.

1. You ask to find something at the moment they stop.
2. The moment, when they stop does not exits.
3. As we know from math courses, any assertions is true for non-existent object.
4. It means, that formally any answer to any input for this puzzle should be accepted as correct.

So, yes, I strongly believe it is necessary to change it :-)

To make the statement formally correct, you can ask to find ball position after time T given in input. And if you like, have tests with very large T (which is kind of equivalent to the current statement).
Or, you can even ask to find ball position after constant T = 10^20 seconds.

You convinced me, I changed it!

Thanks. ðŸ˜

Hey, the balls do stop - the problem, as it is set up, has a limit on the distance traveled by the ball.

lim_{t->\infty}(position) = starting_position + u/0.8

There is no need for interactions, or using the Euler method to integrate the position. This problem can be calculated analytically, without errors  or the need for epsilons, etc.

Hello WildSmilodon,

I'm sorry for the delay in responding.
I think you are right, the limit defines the stop position, there are two ways to interpret this:

On one hand, the ball does not really stop (because the velocity would never reach 0 with the model we chose).
On the other hand, we can consider that a ball is stopped when we cannot detect any movement by sight.

I won't specify the "epsilon" here, I think it's a kind of repetition.
